title: How to Buy and Sell Bitcoin Legally in Singapore
transcript: If you're in Singapore, we're aware that Binance is probably one of, if not the most popular exchange [music] that people use, but it's not licensed by MAS, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and only a handful are. An MAS license doesn't make an [music] exchange risk-free, but it does hold them to stricter standards on how your money is protected and managed. So, let's go through a few of the ones that are regulated. Starting local, there's Coin Heeko. It's been around since 2014, making it one of the oldest Singaporean platforms, and it was also one of the first to get a full license from MAS. Getting started on the app or web is straightforward. Instead of filling out forms and uploading documents, you can just log in with Syncpass and your details are pulled in automatically. Most people get verified in a few minutes. Once you're in, topping up is easy. You can fund your account with SGD through Pay Now or Fast Bank Transfer. that gives you access to trade over 130 tokens on the exchange. And they've also recently added limit orders, so you can set the price you want and let the trade run automatically. And recurring buys, if you want to dollar cost average without logging in every time, these limit orders and recurring buys come with a 0.5% fee, a bit lower than the 0.6 on normal trades. You'll also incur a flat $2 fee when withdrawing SGD. It's worth noting that Coin Heeko doesn't publish a public proof of reserves. So unlike some global platforms, you don't get that extra third-party confirmation of customer balances. That said, Coin Heeko works best if all you want is a simple way to buy Bitcoin and a few other coins and the peace of mind of using a locally licensed platform. But if you're after an exchange with a broader set of features, the next option to consider is Coinbase. Not that it needs much of an introduction, but Coinbase is the biggest US exchange and since 2023, it's also been fully licensed in Singapore. Now, we've seen how Coin Hecko keeps things basic. [music] Coinbase, on the other hand, gives you a choice. You can stick with a simple setup or switch to advanced trade with full order books, trading view charts, and more order types. The token lineup is wider, too. More than 200 assets compared to Coin Heeko's 130. And just like Coin Heeko, onboarding is [music] smooth. With Sing Pass, you can be verified in minutes. And from there, deposits and withdrawals in SGD run straight through pay now or fast bank transfers. When it comes to fees, the two modes make a big difference. If you're using the simple interface, you'll pay a spread plus a transaction fee, which usually works out higher than what you'd see on other licensed exchanges. If you switch to advanced trade, the fees drop to 0.6% for takers and 0.4% for makers with further discounts if you trade larger volumes. Beyond trading, if you hold USDC, you can earn around 4% yield. This yield can be boosted through their paid plan, Coinbase 1, [music] which starts at about 50 Singaporean dollars a year, which on top of better rewards, gives you zero trading fees up to a cap, account protection, and priority support. Coinbase doesn't publish proof of reserves, at least not in the user verifiable Merkel tree style that some other exchanges [music] use, but as a public company, it does file audited financial statements. If you want another global name with just as many products, taking a look at crypto.com. They're also fully licensed in Singapore. But what makes them stand out is their Visa card. [music] It lets you spend your crypto like cash in Singapore. The card itself comes in [music] different tiers. The higher the tier, the more CRO you have to lock up, and you get cash back paid in their token whenever [music] you spend. The catch is that ATM withdrawals are not supported within Singapore. [music] Just like Coinbase, Crypto.com really has two modes. The main app is beginnerfriendly. [music] You can deposit or withdraw Singapore dollars easily through fast and buy [music] or sell with a couple of taps. The trade-off is that prices there include a spread, which makes it more expensive. [music] If you care about tighter pricing, that is where the Crypto.com exchange comes in. It gives you a full order book with lower maker and taker fees, and you can move funds between the app and the exchange instantly and [music] for free. The token coverage is broad, over 400 supported, which means you'll find more niche altcoins here than on Coin Heeko or Coinbase. Crypto.com also offers onchain staking, liquid staking, [music] and DeFi staking, but MAS rules mean those are restricted to accredited investors [music] in Singapore. And this one's worth a look if low trading fees are a priority for you.
